Package com.telenav.kivakit.metrics.core.statistics

Class AggregateMetric<T extends com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.value.DoubleValued>

com.telenav.kivakit.metrics.core.statistics.AggregateMetric<T>
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.telenav.kivakit.core.time.CreatedAt, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.collection.Addable<T>, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.collection.Emptiness, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.collection.Sized, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.collection.SpaceLimited, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.naming.Named, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.numeric.Zeroable, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.value.DoubleValued, com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.value.LongValued, AggregateMetric<T>, Metric<T>
Direct Known Subclasses:
AverageMetric, MaximumMetric, MinimumMetric, TotalMetric
public abstract class AggregateMetric<T extends com.telenav.kivakit.interfaces.value.DoubleValued> extends BaseMetric<T> implements AggregateMetric<T>
A quantum aggregate metric is an AggregateMetric for arbitrary LongValued objects. The DoubleValued.doubleValue() ()} method yields each object's quantum value (a double precision floating point number) when it is added to the aggregate with onAdd(DoubleValued). Aggregation maintains these measurements for the quanta that are added:

Aggregate Metrics

  • total()
  • sampleCount()
  • maximumSample()
  • minimumSample()

When the Metric.measurement() method is called, the subclass' implementation of compute() uses the aggregate metrics to compute a quantum value. For example, the AverageMetric class implements compute() like this: 

 protected double compute()
 {
     return total() / count();
 }

As expected, the average of the quanta is the total quanta divided by the number of quanta. The measurement() method then uses the Mapper passed to the constructor to turn the computed quanta (the average value in this case) back into an object of type T. The result of this design is that aggregate metrics are very easy to implement. The full implementation of AverageMetric is just: 

 public class AverageMetric<T extends QuantizableMetric> extends AggregateMetric<T>
 {
     public AverageMetric(Mapper<Long, T> factory)
     {
         super(factory);
     }

     protected long compute()
     {
         return total() / count();
     }
 }

AverageMetric then serves as the base class for a variety of trivially implemented averages. For example, AverageCountMetric is implemented like this: 

 public class AverageCountMetric extends AverageMetric<Count>
 {
     public AverageCountMetric()
     {
         super(Count::count);
     }
 }

Here, the Count.count(long) factory method is passed to the superclass. This factory method converts the average quantum of the Count objects added to the AggregateMetric back into a Count.

Author:
jonathanl (shibo)

    • subtract

      public boolean subtract(T metric)
      Removes the given metric value from this aggregate. The maximum and minimum sample cannot be reversed since it's not known what the previous maximum or minimum were without the sample to be removed.
      Parameters:
      metric - The metric to remove
      Returns:
      True if it was removed
